segment.tokens: There is a water dog at Hastings
belonging to Page the boatman
the boatman receiving a penny immediately takes it to a baker 's shop for the purchase of a roll
will he part with it
the person serves him
till the person has put the bread upon the counter
he then lays it down
he walks off with his purchase in his mouth
Another dog of this kind also of my acquaintance was the family
is
that she carried books work etc. to any person
any room pointed out to her
as we rather encroached on her
she lost almost all her teeth from the hard and heavy burthens with which she was laden
from the hard and heavy burthens with which she was laden
We had only to say " "
Cora take this to so so
if the good dog could not find the person
she brought it back
she stood before us
At the same hour every afternoon she untold brought her master boot-jack slippers into his study to be in readiness for his return
Under the despised name of curs Colonel Smith classes the sharpest the drollest the most pertinacious the most mischievous yet the most useful terrier with several other small dogs

Long-haired rough-haired long-eared short-eared brush-tailed smooth-tailed long-legged short-legged black-eyed black-nosed white brown black tan sandy mixed every degree of pure or mongrel blood terriers of all kinds swarm around us
playing all sorts of antics
evincing all kinds of impertinences
catching all sorts of vermin
presenting themselves to us in every shape of beauty or ugliness , of which their race is capable
in every shape of beauty or ugliness , of which their race is capable
if not respectable tribe of dogs indeed the most ancient dog of Great Britain is the Scotch
The most ancient of this influential brought to us probably from the north-west of Europe by our primitive inhabitants

There are two varieties of indigenous terriers -- the one , smooth , usually white or black in colour , with tan spots ; sharp muzzle ; bright and lively eyes ; pointed or slightly turned-down ears ; and tail carried high
carried high
It is however
supposed
that the Scottish race with a shorter and fuller muzzle , stouter limbs , hard , shaggy fur , sometimes white in colour , but more often sandy or ochry is the oldest most genuine
named Peter
One of these clever and excellent beasts , named Peter , lived with my mother for some years during the whole of that time evinced the greatest sagacity and attachment
evinced the greatest sagacity attachment
He constantly understood the conversation "
provided
it related to cats , rats , or himself
often when we spoke of him casually even knowing calling him by his name
he was in the room
he has laid his head on our knees as much as to say "
he wagged his tail
I understand
He was a most inveterate to all rats , mice , and cats nipping them in the back of the neck throwing them over his head at the rate of one in a minute
Before he came into our family
he won a wager
that he would kill twelve rats in twelve minutes
the second rat fastened on his lip
the second rat hung there
while he despatched the other ten
given
then within the given time he finished that also
The inhumanity of such wagers did not rest with him
He was stolen more than once
He brought back
when a reward was advertised
the first time the signs suffering about him were very
The beard under the chin the tufts of the ears the fringes of the legs had been all cut off
he had been rubbed with red ochre to disguise him for sale

He was placed with many others in a cellar , ready for shipping , and the dog-dealer , or rather dog-stealer , who brought him to us , said he thought he would have died of grief in a day or two , for he refused to eat , and seemed to be insensible either to kindness or anger
many others in a cellar ready for shipping , and the dog-dealer , rather dog-stealer brought him to us
many others in a cellar ready for shipping , and the dog-dealer , rather dog-stealer said
he thought
he would have died of grief in a day or two
for he refused to eat
many others in a cellar ready for shipping , and the dog-dealer , rather dog-stealer seemed
For three weeks he hung his head
he shrunk into corners
as if he felt himself degraded
at last our caresses encouragement brought back his usual bold lively bearing
For the last three months of my mother 's existence Peter was almost always on her bed , night and day he dull
when death was daily expected
during the final four weeks he was dull
which was attributed to the change in the habits of the family
Forty-eight hours before all was over
Peter crept into a corner under the bed , which had always been his place of refuge when in trouble
the bed had always been his of refuge when in trouble
we with difficulty prevailed on him to quit it
even when his mistress wished to see
we say farewell to him
On that occasion he hung his head
he appeared
that apprehensions of malady on his part were entertained
He returned to his corner
He was not thought of for some time
At length all was in the room I about to leave it
was
when I recollected Peter
He was with difficulty prevailed on to leave his corner , where he lay , curled up and trembling
prevailed on to leave his corner , where he lay , curled up and trembling
where he lay
his corner curled up
I lifted him up to take a last look of his beloved mistress
he laid his head on my shoulder
he was so much
that I carried him away immediately
On the following day he accompanied me up stairs "
when I passed my mother door
he looked up in my face as much as to say "
Are you going in there
but I replied " No "
and he never again asked for entrance
The coffin was soldered down
The coffin removed from the bed-room to the dining-room
The coffin thus had to pass the drawing-room
where all the family were assembled
On ordinary occasions Peter was at the sound of strange footsteps in the house
Peter even barked loudly
when any one knocked at the street-door
any one rang
On this occasion however he suffered the men
employed to pass
he repass frequently making the slightest noise
that he was of some unusual occurrence
but was from his jumping into my arms
as the coffin was brought down
where he sat with ears erect , and eyes fixed , and panted and trembled in the most agitated manner till all was quiet
fixed
panted
trembled
till all was
As long as the body remained in the house
he took every opportunity walking lying under it
round it
when it was removed at five o'clock one morning to begin its journey to the family vault
he was again much agitated
he never offered to bark
On the following day I others started to attend the funeral at a considerable distance
my daughters were to arrive at eight o'clock to pass the day in the house of their deceased grandmother
I took leave of Peter "
I placed him on a mat in the hall
I said "
Stay there
till the girls come
He laid himself down
the servants assured me
he never moved
till the parties arrived
when he met them
subdued
looks
closely attached himself to them as long
as they were
I returned two hours after midnight
the first sound I heard
when the carriage stopped at the door
the first sound was a noisy of joy from Peter
He thenceforward resumed all his usual habits
barking on all occasions
he never was quite the in disposition
He grew indifferent to every one except my brother , never played again ; and four years
never played again
after was found dead in his corner of refuge
